Topological transitivity and wandering intervals for group actions on the line ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}

Enhui Shi
School of Mathematical Sciences
Soochow University
Suzhou 215006, P. R. China
E-mail: ehshi@suda.edu.cn

Lizhen Zhou
School of Mathematical Sciences
Soochow University
Suzhou 215006, P. R. China

Abstract

For every group Gùê∫G, we show that either Gùê∫G has a topologically transitive action on the line ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms, or every orientation-preserving action of Gùê∫G on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} has a wandering interval. According to this result, all groups are divided into two types: transitive type and wandering type, and the types of several groups are determined. We also show that every finitely generated orderable group of wandering type is indicable. As a corollary, we show that if a higher rank lattice ŒìŒì\Gamma is orderable, then ŒìŒì\Gamma is of transitive type.

‚Ä†‚Ä†2010 Mathematics Subject Classification: Primary 37B05; Secondary 37E99.‚Ä†‚Ä†Key words and phrases: topological transitivity; orderable group; indicable group.

Let œïitalic-œï\phi be an action of group Gùê∫G on a topological space XùëãX. The action œïitalic-œï\phi (or Gùê∫G) is said to be topologically transitive, if for every nonempty open subsets UùëàU and VùëâV of XùëãX, there is some g‚ààGùëîùê∫g\in G such that g‚Äã(U)‚à©V‚â†‚àÖùëîùëàùëâg(U)\cap V\not=\emptyset. It is well known that, when Gùê∫G is countable and XùëãX is a Polish space, Gùê∫G is topologically transitive if and only if there is a point x‚ààXùë•ùëãx\in X such that the orbit G‚Äãxùê∫ùë•Gx is dense in XùëãX. Furthermore, Gùê∫G is said to be minimal if for every x‚ààXùë•ùëãx\in X the orbit G‚Äãxùê∫ùë•Gx is dense in XùëãX; this is equivalent to saying that there is no proper Gùê∫G-invariant nonempty closed subset of XùëãX. A closed subset YùëåY of XùëãX is said to be minimal, if YùëåY is Gùê∫G-invariant and the restriction action G|Yevaluated-atùê∫ùëåG|_{Y} of Gùê∫G to YùëåY is minimal. An argument using Zorn‚Äôs lemma shows the existence of minimal sets when XùëãX is a compact metric space, but this is not true in general when XùëãX is not compact.

2 Background and main results

The dynamical system for group actions on one-manifolds has been intensively studied. One may consult [7, 11] for a systematic introduction to this area. Group actions on the real line ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} are closely related to the study of orderability of a group. In fact, a countable group Gùê∫G is orderable (that is, Gùê∫G admits a left-invariant total order relation) if and only if it admits a faithful orientation-preserving action on the real line (see [12, Prop. 2.1]). Many important groups coming from geometry and topology are known to be orderable or nonorderable (see e.g. [3, 5, 17, 20]). In addition, an orderable group may possess some interesting algebraic properties (see e.g. [10, 13, 19]).

The purpose of the paper is to classify group actions on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by means of topological transitivity. One may consult [16] for some related investigations. We first give the following dichotomy theorem.

Theorem 2.1.

Let Gùê∫G be a group. Then either Gùê∫G has a topologically transitive action on the line ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms, or every orientation-preserving action of Gùê∫G on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} has a wandering interval.

We should note that the ‚Äúdichotomy phenomenon‚Äù in Theorem 2.1 is far from being true for group actions on spaces of dimension ‚â•2absent2\geq 2. For example, if Dùê∑D is the closed unit disk in the plane and S2superscriptùëÜ2S^{2} is the unit sphere in ‚Ñù3superscript‚Ñù3\mathbb{R}^{3}, then any one point union of Dùê∑D and S2superscriptùëÜ2S^{2} admits no topologically transitive homeomorphism but admits a homeomorphism with no wandering open set.

Theorem 2.1 motivates us to give the following definition.

Definition 2.2.

A group Gùê∫G is of transitive type if it has a topologically transitive action on the line ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms; it is of wandering type if every orientation-preserving action of Gùê∫G on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} has a wandering interval.

Recall that a group Gùê∫G is poly-cyclic (resp. super-poly-cyclic) if it admits a decreasing sequence of subgroups G=N0‚ä≥N1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Nk={e}ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùëÅ0subscriptùëÅ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅùëòùëíG=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} for some positive integer kùëòk such that Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i+1} is normal in NisubscriptùëÅùëñN_{i} (resp. Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i+1} is normal in Gùê∫G) and Ni/Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñsubscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i}/N_{i+1} is cyclic for each i‚â§k‚àí1ùëñùëò1i\leq k-1; it is called poly-infinite-cyclic (resp. super-poly-infinite-cyclic) if Ni/Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñsubscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i}/N_{i+1} is infinitely cyclic for each i‚â§k‚àí1ùëñùëò1i\leq k-1. It is well known that all poly-cyclic groups are solvable and all finitely generated torsion free nilpotent groups are super-poly-infinite-cyclic.

For each integer nùëõn, the Baumslag-Solitar group B‚Äã(1,n)ùêµ1ùëõB(1,n) is the group ‚ü®a,b:b‚Äãa=an‚Äãb‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©:ùëéùëèùëèùëésuperscriptùëéùëõùëè\langle a,b:ba=a^{n}b\rangle; B‚Äã(1,‚àí1)ùêµ11B(1,-1) is the fundamental group of the Klein Bottle, which is a classical example being of orderable but not bi-orderable (see [11, Exercise 2.2.68]).

Theorem 2.3.

The following groups are of transitive type: the nonabelian free group ‚Ñ§‚àó‚Ñ§‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z}; any super-poly-infinite-cyclic group G=N0‚ä≥N1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Nk={e}ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùëÅ0subscriptùëÅ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅùëòùëíG=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} having the name (n0,n1,‚Ä¶,nk‚àí2)subscriptùëõ0subscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëõùëò2(n_{0},n_{1},...,n_{k-2}) with some ni=1subscriptùëõùëñ1n_{i}=1; any poly-infinite-cyclic, non super-poly-infinite-cyclic group Gùê∫G; the Baumslag-Solitar group B‚Äã(1,n)ùêµ1ùëõB(1,n) with n‚â†0ùëõ0n\not=0 and n‚â†‚àí1ùëõ1n\not=-1.

The following groups are of wandering type: finite groups; the infinite cyclic group ‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}; S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêø2‚Ñ§SL(2,\mathbb{Z}); finite index subgroups of S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêøùëõ‚Ñ§SL(n,\mathbb{Z}) with n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3; any super-poly-infinite-cyclic group G=N0‚ä≥N1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Nk={e}ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùëÅ0subscriptùëÅ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅùëòùëíG=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} having the name (‚àí1,‚àí1,‚Ä¶,‚àí1)11‚Ä¶1(-1,-1,...,-1); the Baumslag-Solitar group B‚Äã(1,‚àí1)ùêµ11B(1,-1).

Recall that a group is indicable if it has a homomorphism onto the infinite cyclic group. One may consult [2, 8, 19] for the discussions about indicability of orderable groups.

Theorem 2.4.

If Gùê∫G is a finitely generated nontrivial orderable group of wandering type, then Gùê∫G is indicable.

A higher rank lattice is a lattice of a simple Lie group with finite center and with real rank ‚â•2absent2\geq 2. The 1-dimensional Zimmer‚Äôs rigidity conjecture says that every continuous action of a higher rank lattice on the circle ùïä1superscriptùïä1\mathbb{S}^{1} must factor through a finite group action. Though the conjecture is still open now, Ghys (see [6]) and Burger-Monod (see [4]) proved independently the existence of periodic points for such actions. This implies that 1-dimensional Zimmer‚Äôs rigidity conjecture is equivalent to that no higher rank lattice is orderable. We get immediately the following corollary by Theorem 2.4 and Theorem 6.5 in the appendix.

Corollary 2.5.

Suppose Gùê∫G is a higher rank lattice. If Gùê∫G is orderable, then it is of transitive type.

3 The dichotomy theorem

Lemma 3.1.

Let Gùê∫G be a group. Suppose Gùê∫G has no topologically transitive action on the line ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms. Then, for every action œï:G‚ÜíHomeo+‚Äã(‚Ñù):italic-œï‚Üíùê∫subscriptHomeo‚Ñù\phi:G\rightarrow{\rm Homeo}_{+}(\mathbb{R}) and for every x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in\mathbb{R}, G‚Äãx¬Ø¬Øùê∫ùë•\overline{Gx} is countable; in particular, G‚Äãx¬Ø¬Øùê∫ùë•\overline{Gx} is nowhere dense.

Proof.

Assume to the contrary that there is some action œï0:G‚ÜíHomeo+‚Äã(‚Ñù):subscriptitalic-œï0‚Üíùê∫subscriptHomeo‚Ñù\phi_{0}:G\rightarrow{\rm Homeo}_{+}(\mathbb{R}) and some x0‚àà‚Ñùsubscriptùë•0‚Ñùx_{0}\in\mathbb{R} such that G‚Äãx0¬Ø¬Øùê∫subscriptùë•0\overline{Gx_{0}} is uncountable. Then, by collapsing the maximal open intervals of ‚Ñù‚àñG‚Äãx0¬Ø‚Ñù¬Øùê∫subscriptùë•0\mathbb{R}\setminus\overline{Gx_{0}}, we get an induced topologically transitive action of Gùê∫G on either [0,1]01[0,1], or [0,1)01[0,1), or (0,1]01(0,1], or (0,1)01(0,1). By removing the endpoints of the phase space of the induced action if necessary, we get a topologically transitive action of Gùê∫G on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms. This contradicts the assumption.

Proof of Theorem 2.1. Assume to the contrary that the following two items hold simultaneously:

4 Types of some groups

Proposition 4.3.

Suppose G=N0‚ä≥N1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Nk={e}ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùëÅ0subscriptùëÅ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅùëòùëíG=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} is super-poly-infinite-cyclic with k‚â•2ùëò2k\geq 2 and has the name (n0,n1,‚Ä¶,nk‚àí2)subscriptùëõ0subscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëõùëò2(n_{0},n_{1},...,n_{k-2}) with some ni=1subscriptùëõùëñ1n_{i}=1. Then Gùê∫G is of transitive type.

Proof.

If nk‚àí2=1subscriptùëõùëò21n_{k-2}=1, then Nk‚àí2subscriptùëÅùëò2N_{k-2} is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§2superscript‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^{2}, which is of transitive type by Example 1.2. By repeated applications of Lemma 4.2, we get that Gùê∫G is of transitive type. If ni=1subscriptùëõùëñ1n_{i}=1 for some i<k‚àí2ùëñùëò2i<k-2, then G/Ni+2ùê∫subscriptùëÅùëñ2G/N_{i+2} is of transitive type by the previous argument. Since G/Ni+2ùê∫subscriptùëÅùëñ2G/N_{i+2} is a factor of Gùê∫G, Gùê∫G is of transitive type. ‚àé

Proposition 4.4.

Suppose Gùê∫G is poly-infinite-cyclic. If Gùê∫G is not super-poly-cyclic, then Gùê∫G is of transitive type.

Proof.

By Proposition 6.4 in the appendix, there is a decreasing sequence of normal subgroups of Gùê∫G: G=N0‚ä≥N1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Nk={e}ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùëÅ0subscriptùëÅ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅùëòùëíG=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} for some k>0ùëò0k>0, such that each Ni/Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñsubscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i}/N_{i+1} is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§disuperscript‚Ñ§subscriptùëëùëñ{\mathbb{Z}}^{d_{i}} for some di‚â•1subscriptùëëùëñ1d_{i}\geq 1. If every Ni/Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñsubscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i}/N_{i+1} is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§‚Ñ§{\mathbb{Z}}, then Gùê∫G is super-poly-cyclic, which contradicts the assumption. So, there is some i‚Ä≤superscriptùëñ‚Ä≤i^{\prime} such that Ni‚Ä≤/Ni‚Ä≤+1subscriptùëÅsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùëÅsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤1N_{i^{\prime}}/N_{i^{\prime}+1} is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§di‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñ§subscriptùëësuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤{\mathbb{Z}}^{d_{i^{\prime}}} with di‚Ä≤‚â•2subscriptùëësuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤2d_{i^{\prime}}\geq 2. Let G~=G/Ni‚Ä≤+1~ùê∫ùê∫subscriptùëÅsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤1{\tilde{G}}=G/N_{i^{\prime}+1}. Since N~i‚Ä≤‚â°Ni‚Ä≤/Ni‚Ä≤+1subscript~ùëÅsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùëÅsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùëÅsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤1\tilde{N}_{i^{\prime}}\equiv N_{i^{\prime}}/N_{i^{\prime}+1} is of transitive type by Example 1.2, G~~ùê∫{\tilde{G}} is of transitive type by repeated applications of Lemma 4.2 (note that G~/N~i‚Ä≤~ùê∫subscript~ùëÅsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤{\tilde{G}}/\tilde{N}_{i^{\prime}} is poly-infinite-cyclic). Then Gùê∫G is of transitive type since G~~ùê∫\tilde{G} is a factor of Gùê∫G. ‚àé

It follows from Claim D that JùêΩJ is a wandering interval for œïitalic-œï\phi.

(‚áê)‚áê(\Leftarrow) Since B‚Äã(1,1)ùêµ11B(1,1) is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§2superscript‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^{2}, it is of transitive type by Example 1.2. ‚àé

From example 1.1, we see that the free nonabelian group ‚Ñ§‚àó‚Ñ§‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z} has a topologically transitive action on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms, since ‚Ñ§2superscript‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^{2} is a factor of ‚Ñ§‚àó‚Ñ§‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z}. In fact, we can further require the action to be faithful as the following lemma shows.

Proposition 4.6.

The free nonabelian group ‚Ñ§‚àó‚Ñ§‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z} has a faithful topologically transitive action on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms.

Proof.

Let f,g‚ààHomeo+‚Äã(‚Ñù)ùëìùëîsubscriptHomeo‚Ñùf,g\in{\rm Homeo}_{+}(\mathbb{R}) be defined by f‚Äã(x)=x+1ùëìùë•ùë•1f(x)=x+1 and g‚Äã(x)=x3ùëîùë•superscriptùë•3g(x)=x^{3} for every x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in\mathbb{R}. Then for any nonempty open intervals UùëàU and VùëâV in ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}, we have diam‚Äã(gn‚Äã(U))>1diamsuperscriptùëîùëõùëà1{\rm diam}(g^{n}(U))>1 for some integer nùëõn, and then there is some integer mùëöm such that fm‚Äã(gn‚Äã(U))‚à©V‚â†‚àÖsuperscriptùëìùëösuperscriptùëîùëõùëàùëâf^{m}(g^{n}(U))\cap V\not=\emptyset. Thus the action by the group HùêªH generated by fùëìf and gùëîg is topologically transitive. By the main result in [18], we see that HùêªH is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§‚àó‚Ñ§‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z}. ‚àé

The following theorem is due to D. Witte-Morris (see [20]).

Theorem 4.7 (Witte-Morris).

The group S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêø2‚Ñ§SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) and all finite index subgroups of S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêøùëõ‚Ñ§SL(n,\mathbb{Z}) with n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3 are non-orderable.

Proposition 4.8.

The group S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêø2‚Ñ§SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) and all finite index subgroups of S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêøùëõ‚Ñ§SL(n,\mathbb{Z}) with n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3 are of wandering type.

Proof.

Since S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêø2‚Ñ§SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) is generated by elements with finite orders, any orientation preserving action of S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêø2‚Ñ§SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} must be trivial. So, S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêø2‚Ñ§SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) is of wandering type. Suppose n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3 and HùêªH is a subgroup of S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêøùëõ‚Ñ§SL(n,\mathbb{Z}) with finite index. Assume HùêªH is of transitive type and let œï:H‚ÜíHomeo+‚Äã(‚Ñù):italic-œï‚ÜíùêªsubscriptHomeo‚Ñù\phi:H\rightarrow{\rm Homeo}_{+}(\mathbb{R}) be a topologically transitive action of HùêªH on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}. By Selberg‚Äôs Lemma (see Theorem 6.6 in the appendix), there is a torsion free normal subgroup FùêπF of HùêªH which has finite index in HùêªH. It follows from Theorem 6.5 (see the appendix) and the topological transitivity of œïitalic-œï\phi that Ker‚Äã(œï)Keritalic-œï{\rm Ker}(\phi) is finite, which implies that Ker‚Äã(œï)‚à©FKeritalic-œïùêπ{\rm Ker}(\phi)\cap F is trivial. So the restriction œï|F:F‚ÜíHomeo+‚Äã(‚Ñù):evaluated-atitalic-œïùêπ‚ÜíùêπsubscriptHomeo‚Ñù\phi|_{F}:F\rightarrow{\rm Homeo}_{+}(\mathbb{R}) is injective. Thus FùêπF is orderable, which contradicts Theorem 4.7. ‚àé

Remark 4.9.

Since the free non-abelian group ‚Ñ§‚àó‚Ñ§‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z} is a finite index subgroup of S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêø2‚Ñ§SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) and ‚Ñ§‚àó‚Ñ§‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z} is of transitive type, Proposition 4.8 does not hold for finite index subgroups of S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñ§)ùëÜùêø2‚Ñ§SL(2,\mathbb{Z}).

Then Theorem 2.3 follows from all the propositions in this section.

5 Indicability

To prove Theorem 2.4, we need several well-known results about group actions on ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}. The following lemma can be shown by the dynamical realization method (see [11, Theorem 2.2.19] and its remark).

Lemma 5.1.

Every countable nontrivial orderable group has a faithful orientation-preserving action on the line ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} without fixed points.

The following lemma is the combination of [11, Proposition 2.1.12] and the remarks after it (see also [9]).

Lemma 5.2.

If Gùê∫G is a finitely generated group acting on the line ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms, then Gùê∫G admits a nonempty minimal closed subset ŒõŒõ\Lambda of ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}, and ŒõŒõ\Lambda has four possibilities:

(a) ŒõŒõ\Lambda is a point (in this case, ŒõŒõ\Lambda is a fixed point of Gùê∫G);

(b) ŒõŒõ\Lambda is an infinite sequence (an)n‚àà‚Ñ§subscriptsubscriptùëéùëõùëõ‚Ñ§(a_{n})_{n\in\mathbb{Z}} satisfying an<an+1subscriptùëéùëõsubscriptùëéùëõ1a_{n}<a_{n+1} for all nùëõn and without accumulation points in ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R};

(c) ŒõŒõ\Lambda is locally a Cantor set;

(d) Œõ=‚ÑùŒõ‚Ñù\Lambda=\mathbb{R}.

Proof of Proposition 2.5. Suppose Gùê∫G is a finitely generated nontrivial orderable group of wandering type. From Lemma 5.1, we can fix a faithful action œï:G‚ÜíHomeo+‚Äã(‚Ñù):italic-œï‚Üíùê∫subscriptHomeo‚Ñù\phi:G\rightarrow{\rm Homeo}_{+}(\mathbb{R}) without fixed points. By Definition 2.2 and Lemma 3.1, we see that ŒõŒõ\Lambda is countable, which together with Lemma 5.2 implies that ŒõŒõ\Lambda is an infinite sequence (an)n‚àà‚Ñ§subscriptsubscriptùëéùëõùëõ‚Ñ§(a_{n})_{n\in\mathbb{Z}} satisfying an<an+1subscriptùëéùëõsubscriptùëéùëõ1a_{n}<a_{n+1} for all nùëõn and without accumulation points in ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}. Set H={g‚ààG:g‚Äã((a0,a1))=(a0,a1)}ùêªconditional-setùëîùê∫ùëîsubscriptùëé0subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé0subscriptùëé1H=\{g\in G:g((a_{0},a_{1}))=(a_{0},a_{1})\} and fix an f‚ààGùëìùê∫f\in G with f‚Äã(a0)=a1ùëìsubscriptùëé0subscriptùëé1f(a_{0})=a_{1}. 6 Appendix

In this section, we first supply some basic results about poly-cyclic groups, which have been used in the precious sections. One may consult [14] for more details.

Proposition 6.1.

Let Gùê∫G be a poly-cyclic group and let HùêªH be a subgroup of Gùê∫G. Then HùêªH is poly-cyclic.

Proposition 6.2 ([13]).

Let Gùê∫G be a poly-cyclic group. Then Gùê∫G is poly-infinite-cyclic if and only if Gùê∫G is orderable.

Since every subgroup of an orderable group is orderable, we immediately get the the following corollary by Proposition 6.1 and Proposition 6.2.

Corollary 6.3.

Let Gùê∫G be a poly-infinite-cyclic group. Then every non-trivial subgroup of Gùê∫G is poly-infinite-cyclic.

Suppose Gùê∫G is a poly-cyclic group. Then G=N0‚ä≥N1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Nk={e}ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùëÅ0subscriptùëÅ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅùëòùëíG=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} with Ni/Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñsubscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i}/N_{i+1} cyclic for each iùëñi. The cyclic groups Ni/Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñsubscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i}/N_{i+1} are called the cyclic factors. The Hirsch number of Gùê∫G is the number of infinite cyclic factors among these Ni/Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñsubscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i}/N_{i+1}. It is an invariant of polycyclic groups.

Proposition 6.4.

Let Gùê∫G be a poly-infinite-cyclic group. Then there is a decreasing sequence of normal subgroups of Gùê∫G: G=G0‚ä≥G1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Gl={e}ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùê∫0subscriptùê∫1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∫ùëôùëíG=G_{0}\rhd G_{1}\rhd...\rhd G_{l}=\{e\} for some l>0ùëô0l>0, such that Gi/Gi+1subscriptùê∫ùëñsubscriptùê∫ùëñ1G_{i}/G_{i+1} is a free abelian group of finite rank for each iùëñi.

Proof.

Suppose G=N0‚ä≥N1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Nk={e}ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùëÅ0subscriptùëÅ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅùëòùëíG=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} for some k>0ùëò0k>0, where Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i+1} is normal in NisubscriptùëÅùëñN_{i} and Ni/Ni+1subscriptùëÅùëñsubscriptùëÅùëñ1N_{i}/N_{i+1} is infinitely cyclic for each i‚â•0ùëñ0i\geq 0. So, G/[G,G]ùê∫ùê∫ùê∫G/[G,G] is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§d√óFsuperscript‚Ñ§ùëëùêπ\mathbb{Z}^{d}\times F for some d>1ùëë1d>1, where FùêπF is a finite abelian group. Let œÄ:G‚ÜíG/[G,G]:ùúã‚Üíùê∫ùê∫ùê∫ùê∫\pi:G\rightarrow G/[G,G] be the quotient homomorphism and let G1=œÄ‚àí1‚Äã(F)subscriptùê∫1superscriptùúã1ùêπG_{1}=\pi^{-1}(F). Similarly, we can get a character subgroup G2subscriptùê∫2G_{2} of G1subscriptùê∫1G_{1} (which is also a character subgroup of Gùê∫G) such that G1/G2subscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫2G_{1}/G_{2} is a free abelian group of finite rank, since G1subscriptùê∫1G_{1} is still poly-infinite-cyclic by Proposition 6.3. Going on in this way, we get a sequence of character subgroups of G:G=G0‚ä≥G1‚ä≥‚Ä¶‚ä≥Gi‚ä≥‚Ä¶:ùê∫ùê∫contains-as-subgroupsubscriptùê∫0subscriptùê∫1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∫ùëñ‚Ä¶G:G=G_{0}\rhd G_{1}\rhd...\rhd G_{i}\rhd... such that Gi/Gi+1subscriptùê∫ùëñsubscriptùê∫ùëñ1G_{i}/G_{i+1} is a free abelian group of finite rank for each iùëñi. The following theorem is due to Margulis and Kazhdan (see e.g. [21, Theorem 8.1.2]).

Theorem 6.5.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma be a higher rank lattice and let HùêªH be a normal subgroup of ŒìŒì\Gamma. Then either HùêªH is finite or Œì/HŒìùêª\Gamma/H is finite.

The following theorem is known as Selberg‚Äôs Lemma (see [15]).

Theorem 6.6.

Let Gùê∫G be a finitely generated subgroup of G‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚ÑÇ)ùê∫ùêøùëõ‚ÑÇGL(n,\mathbb{C}). Then Gùê∫G contains a torsion free normal subgroup HùêªH with finite index in Gùê∫G.
